text: Quick question: what's the easiest way to do format strings?  Is there an equivalent of `f"My value = {val}"` in python?

elements.text: Quick question: what's the easiest way to do format strings?  Is there an equivalent of
f"My value = {val}"
in python?

text: Printf stdlib (pretty bare, c-style formatting. Formatting.jl has what you want though

elements.text: Printf stdlib (pretty bare, c-style formatting. Formatting.jl has what you want though

text: Ah, OK.  Yeah like my goto now is @sprintf(...)

elements.text: Ah, OK.  Yeah like my goto now is @sprintf(...)
I'll check out formatting.jl, thanks!

text: If you really just want the basics then it's `"My value = $val"`

elements.text: If you really just want the basics then it's
"My value = $val"

text:
Expanding on de Graaf's point: <https://docs.julialang.org/en/v1/manual/strings/#string-interpolation>

Note that if you're trying to interpolate custom types
> Both concatenation and string interpolation call `string` to convert objects into string form. However, `string` actually just returns the output of `print`, so new types should add methods to `print` or `show` instead of `string`.

elements.text: Expanding on de Graaf's point:
Note that if you're trying to interpolate custom types
Both concatenation and string interpolation call
string
to convert objects into string form. However,
string
actually just returns the output of
print
, so new types should add methods to
print
or
show
instead of
string

text: Basically just the least effort way of making pretty strings and error messages

text:
Something I didn't know about at first when learning `$` interpolation : You can also put expressions inside them

`"The length is $(length(a))"`

elements.text: Something I didn't know about at first when learning
interpolation : You can also put expressions inside them
"The length is $(length(a))"

text:
I tend to do things like
`"My val to 3 significant figures $(round(x; sigdigits=3))"`

because i find that easier to read than
`sprintf("My val to 3 significant figures %.3g" , x)`
and because of *magic,* that  seems to always actually work.  Though i feel like it shouldn’t be gareteeed to

text: Please take a look at Strs.jl, it does almost exactly what you are asking for

elements.text: Please take a look at Strs.jl, it does almost exactly what you are asking for

text:
```using Strs

f"My val to 3 significant figures \%.3g(x)"```

elements.text:
using Strs

f"My val to 3 significant figures \%.3g(x)"
